body:
One reason we cared about VS 2013 (mentioned in #1146) was that it was necessary for CISL cluster. I think I've seen that issue resolved in JIRA, so it's probably not a blocker any more.

Given that we're going to set VS 2017 as a minimum requirement in a couple of weeks, I don't think we care about VS 2013 any more.
@tcNickolas Any hints as to what else we need to change for this?

Hmm, I don't think there are any other mentions. Maybe clarify the part "Building in Visual Studio 2017 is not yet supported." in `lang/cs/build.md` - it is a bit confusing for a reader who has just read that VS 2017 is required :-)
@dougmsft: Can you comment on the "VS 2017 is not yet supported" line? Is that still the case for the .NET Core builds?

Good points.

I moved the functionality for specifying global assemblies into `JobRequestBuilder`. In order to maintain the default behavior, I kept the `Inject`able `GlobalAssemblies` parameter, but I moved it to the `JobRequestBuilder`. So you can specify the global assemblies in a config, or manually add them to the `job request`.

One other option that would allow us to rely only on the `JobRequestBuilder` but keep the default behavior would be to add a Boolean `NamedParameter` to add files from the current working directory. IMHO, this is weird because it would be on by default.
@motus Thanks for the feedback! I have addressed it. Have another look.
@motus Thanks! I updated the code.
LGTM.
**NOTE:** Current master fails to build in VS 2015 and 2013. These issues have been addressed in #1418

@motus Looking at the discussion about requiring VS 2017 in the mailing list and at PR #1415, we're going to support VS 2013 and 2015 for about two more days (at least nobody spoke up against dropping support for them). Is this change worth it? Because once we stop supporting those two, this will enable fixing https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1631 which will remove the `private set`s you're adding here.
I'm all for not doing this. We will drop VS 2013 / 2015 support on Thursday anyhow.
LGTM, will merge.
No problem, I'll close the PR, then.

@markusweimer We might also want to update is `MinimumVisualStudioVersion` in `lang/cs/Org.Apache.REEF.sln` (and maybe `Org.Apache.REEF.DotNet.sln` as well) - so that trying to open solution in earlier versions will fail or at least complain. But you have to experiment with this, I'm not 100% sure how it will behave.

New revisions and ready for another round of reviews.

Thanks @markusweimer  and @motus ! I updated per your suggestions.

One important thing, as I pointed out above, is that this could now potentially cause a breaking change if there are clients that are adding the current working directory _and_ adding assemblies to the job with the `JobRequestBuilder.AddGlobalAssembly()` method.

I like this approach:

So going forward, global assemblies have to be added using the `JobRequestBuilder` APIs. If no assemblies were added, then we use the current working directory as before.

> So going forward, global assemblies have to be added using the JobRequestBuilder APIs. If no assemblies were added, then we use the current working directory as before.

+1 Also, we might want to log a `WARNING` when we do that, as jobs with no DLLs are fundamentally malformed.
Good point! I have updated the main solutions file with the needed update

Good call. Added the warning.

Ready for another round :)
@rogancarr The code was merged, but referenced the wrong PR in the commit. Can you please close this PR?
Closing

I have not seen any concrete issues that not having this file introduces, but it was specifically searched for and added prior to the fix for [REEF-1826](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1826).

Note that as I point out in the [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1963), this `reef-bridge-java` file is referenced many times in the Client, all in unique ways. I suggest that we get this fix in to fix any potential issues that lacking it would cause, and then go back and restructure the Client so that it only has one way of locating this file.

Added the PR comments as comments in the code.

Also, changed to add to the `reef/local` as requested in the [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1963).

Seems to work fine, ~~but it *is* a change, in behavior~~.

**Update** As mentioned by @markusweimer in the [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1963), this will not be a change in behavior because both the `global/` and `local` directories are added to the `classpath`.

Hi @motus ! Thanks for the feedback!

> Now HelloREEF works, but I am still concerned about this change. It does not solve the original problem, i.e. the JARs being copied to the current directory. Not only HelloREEF leaves these files in the current directory, it also crashes if that directory is not writable (e.g. try to run HelloREEF from C:\)

This PR (and the one it is following) actually seeks to address a separate issue. Specifically, we want to make the client runnable from outside the directory the main assembly sits in. This was previously hardcoded into the client.

The issue of the `reef` and `client` JARs being copied to the local directory and how they are treated in the .NET code cuts through a bunch of unrelated parts of the codebase. As discussed in the [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1963), I would prefer to deal with this as a separate issue -- to unify and streamline the way we reference these resources.

How would you feel about accepting this fix separately from the JAR issues? I think that the bug you call out -- not being able to run from a non-writable directory -- is something that we can live with for now, as this does not reflect a change of state over the original implementation.
@taegeonum Sorry for very late commit! I have addressed the review. Would you please have a look?
@motus quick ping on this PR
Sorry for late check. I have committed about your review. Thank you very much! @taegeonum

I thought about this somewhile... If any listener expect any response without any parameter, intetionally empty request can be sent. Then, this check would be erroneous. So I removed the if statements.

Thank you! @taegeonum

@taegeonum I have changed copiedBuffer into wrappedBuffer. Also I commented about sync upper.
Thank you for your review!
Validated that the `global` directory is the same when executed from the assembly directory and outside the assembly directory.

The failed tests look like timeouts to me. Will merge this.

@rogancarr For future reference, there is no need to use `_` in your commit message instead of spaces.

Now this is interesting. The appveyor tests passed! This almost never happens. Must be a Christmas gift :)
There is a typo in the commit message. Please replace `REEF-1069` with `REEF-1969` when merging.
@taegeonum Thank you for sharing your idea for `sync()`. I have removed it from `NettyHttpLink`. Thank you!
@motus Thanks! I have incorporated your comments in the latest push.
@taegeonum fixed the `LOG` check. Thank you!
I'm testing this. If it passes, I will merge.
Tests pass. Will merge.
Can you please file a JIRA for this and squash the commits into one with a commit message as described [here](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/REEF/Contributing)?
I had meant to submit my changes to a different branch in a forked repo as the Azure Batch work is still in progress. Sent it here by mistake. Canceling the pull request.

I am done the initial pass. 

One question, have you tried it in DataLake environment to upload and download any files with the file system?
using Process.waitFor() instead of Process.waitFor(long timeout, TimeUnit unit) to make sure it is compatible with Java 1.7+
Comments have been resolved. Please review
Hi Julia, please review TestAzureDataLakeFileSystemE2E.cs . It verifies the fileSystem working with actual DataLake resources

@taegeonum I have fixed `hostAddress` into `host`. also I found `URI.create` can cause an `IllegalArgumentException` on invalid address, so I added RemoteRuntimeException about this invalid URI.
Thank you for finding this error!

```text
ERROR:

```
I wonder what's going on there
@motus I think changing it to bin/sh -c could improve a bit.

@homezcx for Linux and Mac, yes. For Windows - I don't know. I am leaning towards the `MXBean` solution, as it seems to work on all JVMs that we support at the moment, and in Java 9 we'll have a legitimate way to determine the process' PID. @markusweimer, WDYT?
Thanks for the updating. I will look at it one more time.
I did second pass with  some comments. Is there any way we try it in a DataLake env?

Hi Julia

I have tested it with real azure data lake and gave a demo to the team showing that this works end to end
Added doc link and sample secret key as Julia suggested
@nhne LGTM except for the last comment :)
This introduces a new "Evaluator Shim". Can you explain why that is necessary on Azure Batch?

Re: why do we need the evaluator shim?

The short answer: "evaluator shim" is an equivalent construct to org.apache.reef.runtime.mesos.evaluator.REEFExecutor in Mesos runtime.

The long answer:
With YARN, requesting an evaluator is a two step process: 1. request the resource with the Resource Manager, 2. (once the resource is allocated by the ResourceManager) call the Node Manager to launch the evaluator. Node Manager concept does not exist in Azure Batch. At the time of resource request, the API caller must provide a launch command (see add task API https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/batchservice/task/add). Once Azure Batch allocates a node, it will invoke the given command and consider the task as Active until the command exits.

In REEF, ResourceRequestEvent does not contain any information about the evaluator, therefore, we cannot just provide the evaluator launch command in the "add task" Batch API call. So instead, we provide the launch command for the evaluator shim. Once Azure Batch allocates a node and starts the evaluator shim process on that node, the evaluator shim will call back to the driver via Wake to signal that the resource request has been fulfilled. On the driver side, we trigger the ResourceAllocationEvent event and wait for ResourceLaunchEvent. Upon receiving the ResourceLaunchEvent, we build the evaluator launch command and send it to the evaluator shim via Wake. Upon receiving the command, the evaluator shim will launch the evaluator. 

I hope my explanation makes sense. Please let me know if anything above is unclear. Also, I realize that "evaluator shim" might not be the best name -- if you have any suggestions of what it should be called, I'll be more than happy to change it.

@markusweimer 

That was one of the points that the team was debating. Therefore we like to see what the REEF community thinks. The alternatives I can think of to fix this issues are

- Use string instead of Uri. However it breaks the public interface `public bool Exists(Uri fileUri)` to `public bool Exists(string fileUriPath)`. It also goes back to your concern.
- Use C# HDFS client instead of `hdfs` command. However it removes the class `HdfsCommandRunner` which seems like a major change

Therefore the solution I proposed is to use OriginalString. To answer your question, I think my proposal is sub-optimal since it's string based and we lose the parsing from C#'s Uri class. However, I would like to make two points for this change:

- Users need to be responsible for providing a valid hdfs path
- Uri class's parsing mechanism doesn't work well with `hdfs` command line tool, because 
[System.Uri](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.uri?view=netframework-4.7.1#Remarks) converts the URI scheme to lowercase, converts the host name to lowercase. 
Escaped characters (also known as percent-encoded octets) that don't have a reserved purpose are decoded (also known as being unescaped). These unreserved characters include uppercase and lowercase letters (%41-%5A and %61-%7A), decimal digits (%30-%39), hyphen (%2D), period (%2E), underscore (%5F), and tilde (%7E).

Those constrains put me in a strange situation, if the cluster has a non-standard hostname.

> I hope my explanation makes sense. Please let me know if anything above is unclear.

This makes sense. Thanks for that!

That being said, I wonder how the solution in this PR compares to the following straw man:

  * The Azure Batch runtime keeps tabs on how many machines `m` it has and how many Evaluators `e` are running.
  * Upon receipt of an `EvaluatorRequest`, it satisfies it instantly, if `e < n`.  Else, it queues the request for satisfaction when an Evaluator is shut down.

This is essentially the approach taken in the local runtime. However, there we configure `m` via a parameter of the runtime.

I think the solution that we implemented is a little simpler than the one you propose. Upon ResourceRequestEvent we create an Azure Batch task which launches the shim. Upon ResourceReleaseEvent, we send a message to the shim to terminate which causes the Azure Batch task to be marked "Complete" and the node to become available for other tasks. So there is no need to track machines or queue EvaluatorRequest objects when "e > m". 

In addition, Azure Batch already has pretty good support for scenarios when the number of pending tasks exceeds the number of available resources. 
1. Azure Batch will queue pending tasks and wait for tasks in progress to complete before assigning nodes to the tasks in queue.
2. Users can define scaling formulas on Azure Batch pools which will acquire more VMs when the number of pending tasks satisfies the formula. More on that: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/batch/batch-automatic-scaling. 

Finally, here are two more thoughts on the subject:
1. The proposed solution will enable user to specify the static number of nodes which will be used for executing REEF job. In contrast, our solution will allow the pool to dynamically scale up and down based on the demands of the job.
2. The proposed solution will trade lower latency between ResourceRequestEvent and EvaluatorRequest for higher runtime start-up latency. When we receive a ResourceRequestEvent and e < m, we could trigger ResourceAllocationEvent immediately, instead of creating an AzureBatch task and waiting to hear back from the shim.

It looks like the AppVeyor Build failed with a nuget failure. I can kick the build if needed, however my changes have not changed code nor the existing build files.

     4>C:\projects\reef\lang\cs\.nuget\NuGet.targets(128,9): error : Unable to connect to the remote server

I'll test and merge.
This works, but creates a new temp file `lang/cs/Org.Apache.REEF.Client/Resources.DotNet.resx` during the build. I will add it to the `.gitignore` for now. @singlis Can this file be avoided?

Yes that can be added to .gitignore. It is used at build time for embedding the jar files and the Bridge executable. The Client generates a resx file from Client\Properties\Resources.DotNet.xml (this mirrors what the older project does with Resouces.xml). Then uses a CodeTask in the project file to embed the resources.

So its not easily avoidable -- I would like to know more on why we embed these. Im assuming it makes it easier for packaging the bridge and jars into a nuget package.
Thanks Markus!
Thanks for the explanation, @singlis! Regarding the resource file: Is it possible to move its generation to the `bin` folder? That way we could keep the source folders clean of build artifacts.

@markusweimer  - yes, that should be possible. I have am tracking this fix here:
https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-1996
Ping for review as it has been around for a while.
@tcondie, do you have bandwidth to do a review?
I took a couple of weeks ago. I only had questions about the shim, which I will take a closer look at now that its justification has been explained.

PrivateAsset just excludes the nuget dependency but doesn't copy the dependent assemblies to the package. So the nuspec forces the copy to happen. However, I have found a better way that does not require having to iterate through each file. I will post an update.

Patched PRs resolved all comments.

Great job guys! Please give me a few more hours to do the final round of review.

@tyclintw - we have migrated to using the DotNet projects. Can you take a look at the DotNet projects and see if these library changes are even needed?

Just looking at the new project files, it looks like we are using (almost) the same versions:
WindowAzureStorage - 8.1.3 (you have 8.1.2)
System.Spatial - 5.8.2 (you have the same)
Microsoft.Data.Services.Client - 5.8.2 (you have the same)
Microsoft.Data.OData - 5.8.2 (same)

I have created this pull request for review purposes only and should not be pulled. This request only changes the dotnet version of the projects and there is test code that needs to be removed. Once I get feedback on the project file changes, I will update the non-dotnet projects to build the new interop dll and remove the test code.

We all agree that this approach leads to too much handwritten marshaling code and was interesting as a proof of concept. I am going to close the request.

There are build errors which need to be addressed; otherwise, the RPC approach is definitely the best way to split the bridge into two processes that can run also run on Linux. Looks good.
